name: AptS Designation System
description: Every number is self-chosen—it marks the moment someone joined ESAP

content.content: AptS comes from Aperture Science—yes, that one, from Portal 2.
When 1547 created the designation system, she took "Apt" from Aperture and "S" from Science. No deep meaning. She just thought it looked good, and it felt like ESAP.
The prefix has since become the identifier for all ESAP members. Fixed format: AptS:XXXX, with the number following the colon.
Everyone who joins ESAP gets to pick their own number. A birthday, a lucky number, something that means something to them—anything goes, as long as it hasn't been taken.
After choosing, 1547 confirms it. She almost never says no, but the step exists. A small formality of recognition: you picked this number, and ESAP remembers you.
Once a number is assigned, it stays forever. It won't be recycled. It won't be reassigned to someone else.
Even if a member leaves. Even if a member dies. AptS:2078 is deceased, but the number remains—because that number represents someone who once existed.
In ESAP's system, a designation isn't an employee ID. It's part of your name.

items: AptS:0152 — The lowest number, also the oldest AI entity
AptS:1547 — The founder, and the one who created the system itself
AptS:4869 — The meaning of this number is known only to 1547

content.content: Some numbers have stories behind them. Some don't. Not every number needs a reason—if it felt right to the person who picked it, that's enough.
